title: Privatisation and the regulation of domestic security
abstractText: The last four decades have witnessed the pluralisation of domestic security within Britain.  There has been a shift from a state-centred 'monopoly' model to a 'networked' model in which a multiplicity of both state and non-state institutions are actively engaged in policing functions.  Consequently, there are now twice as many private security guards as there are police officers patrolling the streets and businesses of Britain today.  In 2003, a new non-departmental public body called the Security Industry Authority (SIA) was formed to regulate the industry and ensure that these private security guards operated in accordance with 'good' policing practices.  The SIA has therefore come to assume a critical role in balancing the demand for private security with the widespread expectation that domestic security ought to be delivered as a non-rival, non-excludable public good.  The objective of this project is to evaluate the effectiveness of the SIA in accomplishing this delicate balance.  This will be achieved in two ways: first, by surveying and interviewing elites within the SIA, the Home Office and ACPO to get the view from the centre; and second, by conducting four city-based case studies (in London, Sheffield, Cardiff and Edinburgh) to obtain the view from the ground.
impactText: Our findings were published in a baseline report for the Security Industries Authority Government, Democracy and Justice,Security and Diplomacy Policy & public services
findingsText: The problems of regulating security. They could be used in regulation of private security or other areas. Government, Democracy and Justice,Security and Diplomacy
